Q0.reasoning: The clinical note explicitly states the patient is being considered for whole exome sequencing (WES).

Q1.reasoning: UHC WES coverage criteria are focused on pediatric patients with unexplained developmental delay/multiple congenital anomalies; the patient is 3 years old, which satisfies pediatric age-based eligibility.

Q2.reasoning: UHC generally requires an appropriate specialist to order WES (genetics, pediatric subspecialist). The test was referred by a developmental pediatrician, which meets ordering-provider requirements.

Q3.reasoning: UHC medical necessity criteria support WES for patients with multiple congenital anomalies and developmental concerns; the patient has multiple congenital anomalies and developmental referral, meeting indication criteria.

Q4.reasoning: UHC typically requires prior chromosomal microarray (CMA) (and other targeted testing as appropriate) before WES. Only a nondiagnostic karyotype is documented; there is no documentation of prior CMA, so required prior testing has not been completed.

Q5.reasoning: UHC WES criteria do not generally require a specific family history or consanguinity to qualify; although a maternal history of long QT is documented, family-history-based criteria for WES eligibility are not specified in this case.

Q6.reasoning: UHC coverage and best-practice requirements expect documentation of genetic counseling (pre-/post-test) for WES. The record states no genetic counseling has been conducted, so counseling requirements are not met.

Q7.reasoning: CPT 81415 corresponds to clinical exome sequencing (WES) interpretation/reporting and is the appropriate code for WES.

Q8.reasoning: Although age, provider, and clinical indication meet UHC criteria, required prerequisites (documentation of prior CMA or other required prior testing and documented genetic counseling) are missing; therefore under UHC criteria the test is not covered at this time.
